title: USS Coeur de Lion
text:
USS "Coeur de Lion" (1861) (more properly spelled "Cœur de lion", but it is unclear which rendering was actually used) was an armed side-wheeled <a href="Steamboat">steamer</a> acquired by the <a href="Union%20Navy">Union Navy</a> during the <a href="American%20Civil%20War">American Civil War</a>. She served as a <a href="patrol%20boat">patrol boat</a>, capable of engaging the enemy with her powerful guns.
Service with the Union Navy.
"Coeur de Lion", a side wheel steamer, was loaned to the <a href="United%20States%20Department%20of%20the%20Navy">Navy Department</a> by the <a href="United%20States%20Lighthouse%20Board">Lighthouse Board</a> in 1861; outfitted at <a href="New%20York%20Navy%20Yard">New York Navy Yard</a>; and sailed 2 October 1861 for <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>, Acting Master Alexander in command. On 10 November 1861 the "Coeur de Lion" towed the barge <a href="USS%20George%20Washington%20Parke%20Custis%20%281861%29">USS George Washington Parke Custis (1861)</a> the first <a href="de%20facto">de facto</a> aircraft carrier.
Patrolling the Potomac River and tributaries.
Until the end of the war "Coeur de Lion" patrolled in the <a href="Potomac%20River">Potomac River</a>, <a href="James%20River%2C%20Virginia">James River</a>, and other rivers of <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>. She burned the schooners "Charity", "Gazelle", and "Flight" in the <a href="Appomattox%20River">Appomattox River</a> on 27 May 1862 and the schooners "Sarah Margaret" and <a href="Odd%20Fellow">Odd Fellow</a> up the <a href="Coan%20River">Coan River</a> 1 June 1862.
Enforcing the blockade, "Coeur de Lion" captured the schooners "Emily Murray" off <a href="Machodoc%20Creek">Machodoc Creek</a>, <a href="Virginia">Virginia</a>, 9 February 1863, and "Robert Knowles" 16 September 1863, and "Malinda" 3 June 1864, in the Potomac. During a reconnaissance up the <a href="Nansemond%20River">Nansemond River</a>, she exchanged fire with enemy batteries on 17 and 19 April 1863, taking the surrender of one of these on the 19th.
Decommissioning.
Arriving at <a href="Washington%20Navy%20Yard">Washington Navy Yard</a> 15 May 1865, "Coeur de Lion" was decommissioned 2 June 1865 and returned to the <a href="United%20States%20Lighthouse%20Board">Lighthouse Board</a> the following day.
